section.title: euvoc:XlNotation
section.p: A notation is a string of characters used to uniquely identify a concept within a specified context.

Like the skosxl:Label class reifies SKOS label statements, XlNotation reifies SKOS notation statements. This class permits, if needed, to maintain the historical view of the values and add additional provenance descriptions.

entry.p: Date of creation of the resource.
Date of modification of the resource.
End of the validity period. If a resource has an end date then it must be marked as deprecated.
Beginning of the validity period.
States whether the resource is current or deprecated. By deprecating a resource, it means that it should not be used in new documents.
Deprecation is a feature commonly used in versioning software to indicate that a particular feature is preserved for backward-compatibility purposes, but may be phased out in the future.
The literal form of the notation.

row.entry: Specify the context where a specified notation is considered unique.

section.title: euvoc:XlNote
section.p: Like the skosxl:Label class reifies SKOS label statements, XlNote reifies SKOS note statements (i.e. skos:editorialNote, skos:example, skos:historyNote, skos:definition, skos:scopeNote and skos:changeNote). This class permits, if needed, to maintain the historical view of the values and add additional provenance descriptions.

entry.p: Date of creation of the resource.
Date of modification of the resource.
A related resource from which the described resource is derived.

The described resource may be derived from the related resource in whole or in part. Recommended best practice is to identify the related resource by means of a string conforming to a formal identification system.
The literal form of the note.

section.title: rdfs:Resource
section.p: All things described by RDF are called resources, and are instances of the class rdfs:Resource. This is the class of everything.

entry.p: Date of creation of the resource.
Date of modification of the resource.

row.entry: The preferred lexical label for a resource, in a given language. No two concepts in the same concept scheme may have the same preferred label in a given language.

section.title: skos:Concept
section.p: A SKOS concept can be viewed as an idea or notion; a unit of thought. However, what constitutes a unit of thought is subjective, and this definition is meant to be suggestive, rather than restrictive.

The notion of a SKOS concept is useful when describing the conceptual or intellectual structure of a knowledge organization system, and when referring to specific ideas or meanings established within a KOS.

Note that, because SKOS is designed to be a vehicle for representing semi-formal KOS, such as thesauri and classification schemes, a certain amount of flexibility has been built in to the formal definition of this class.

entry.p: Date of creation of the resource.
Date when the resource creation or modification is accepted by the governance committee.
Date when the resource creation or modification is sent for review to the governance committee.
Date of modification of the resource.
End of the validity period. If a resource has an end date then it must be marked as deprecated.
Beginning of the validity period.
Denotes the pragmatic, discursive or technical context of a concept or a constraint on the concept properties.
States whether the resource is current or deprecated. By deprecating a resource, it means that it should not be used in new documents.
Deprecation is a feature commonly used in versioning software to indicate that a particular feature is preserved for backward-compatibility purposes, but may be phased out in the future.
An owl:versionInfo statement generally has as its object a string giving information about this version. This statement does not contribute to the logical meaning of the resource.
An alternative lexical label for a resource. Acronyms, abbreviations, spelling variants, and irregular plural/singular forms may be included among the alternative labels for a concept.
A note about a modification to a concept.
A statement or formal explanation of the meaning of a concept.
A note for an editor, translator or maintainer of the vocabulary.
An example of the use of a concept.

A lexical label for a resource that should be hidden when generating visual displays of the resource, but should still be accessible to free text search operations. Mis-spelled terms are normally included as hidden labels.
A note about the past state/use/meaning of a concept.
A notation is a string of characters such as "T58.5" or "303.4833" used to uniquely identify a concept within the scope of a given concept scheme or within a specified context.
The preferred lexical label for a resource, in a given language. No two concepts in the same concept scheme may have the same preferred label in a given language.
A note that helps to clarify the meaning of a concept.

row.entry: A concept scheme in which the concept is included. A concept may be a member of more than one concept scheme.
A statement or formal explanation of the meaning of a concept.
The properties skos:broadMatch and skos:narrowMatch are used to state a hierarchical mapping link between two concepts.
A note about the past state/use/meaning of a concept.
The properties skos:broadMatch and skos:narrowMatch are used to state a hierarchical mapping link between two concepts.
A concept that is more general in meaning. Broader concepts are typically rendered as parents in a concept hierarchy (tree).
An example of the use of a concept.
A related resource that supplants, displaces, or supersedes the described resource.

The property skos:exactMatch is used to link two concepts, indicating a high degree of confidence that the concepts can be used interchangeably across a wide range of information retrieval applications.
The property skos:closeMatch is used to link two concepts that are sufficiently similar that they can be used interchangeably in some information retrieval applications.
The property skos:relatedMatch is used to state an associative mapping link between two concepts.
A concept that is less general in meaning. Narrower concepts are typically rendered as children in a concept hierarchy (tree).
An alternative lexical label for a resource. Acronyms, abbreviations, spelling variants, and irregular plural/singular forms may be included among the alternative labels for a concept.

A lexical label for a resource that should be hidden when generating visual displays of the resource, but should still be accessible to free text search operations. Mis-spelled terms are normally included as hidden labels.
The property skos:hasTopConcept is, by convention, used to link a concept scheme to the SKOS concept(s) which are topmost in the hierarchical relations for that scheme.
The preferred lexical label for a resource, in a given language. No two concepts in the same concept scheme may have the same preferred label in a given language.
A notation is a string of characters such as "T58.5" or "303.4833" used to uniquely identify a concept within the scope of a given concept scheme or within a specified context.
A related resource that is supplanted, displaced, or superseded by the described resource.
A concept with which there is an associative semantic relationship.
A note about a modification to a concept.
A note for an editor, translator or maintainer of the vocabulary.
A note that helps to clarify the meaning of a concept.
The properties skos:broadMatch and skos:narrowMatch are used to state a hierarchical mapping link between two concepts.
The properties skos:broadMatch and skos:narrowMatch are used to state a hierarchical mapping link between two concepts.
A concept that is more general in meaning. Broader concepts are typically rendered as parents in a concept hierarchy (tree).
A related resource that supplants, displaces, or supersedes the described resource.

The property skos:exactMatch is used to link two concepts, indicating a high degree of confidence that the concepts can be used interchangeably across a wide range of information retrieval applications.
The property skos:closeMatch is used to link two concepts that are sufficiently similar that they can be used interchangeably in some information retrieval applications.
The property skos:relatedMatch is used to state an associative mapping link between two concepts.
A concept that is less general in meaning. Narrower concepts are typically rendered as children in a concept hierarchy (tree).
A related resource that is supplanted, displaced, or superseded by the described resource.
A concept with which there is an associative semantic relationship.

section.title: skos:ConceptScheme
section.p: A SKOS concept scheme can be viewed as an aggregation of one or more SKOS concepts. Semantic relationships (links) between those concepts may also be viewed as part of a concept scheme. This definition is, however, meant to be suggestive rather than restrictive, and there is some flexibility in the formal data model stated below.

Thesauri, classification schemes, subject heading lists, taxonomies, 'folksonomies', and other types of controlled vocabulary are all examples of concept schemes. Concept schemes are also embedded in glossaries and terminologies.

entry.p: Date of creation of the resource.
An unambiguous reference to the resource within a given context.
Recommended best practice is to identify the resource by means of a string conforming to a formal identification system.
Date of modification of the resource.
An owl:versionInfo statement generally has as its object a string giving information about this version. This statement does not contribute to the logical meaning of the resource.
An alternative lexical label for a resource. Acronyms, abbreviations, spelling variants, and irregular plural/singular forms may be included among the alternative labels for a concept.
The preferred lexical label for a resource, in a given language. No two concepts in the same concept scheme may have the same preferred label in a given language.

row.entry: A related resource that is included either physically or logically in the described resource.
Indicates the subject of the controlled vocabulary. This property has a similar function as the dct:subject and dcat:theme.
A related resource in which the described resource is physically or logically included.
The preferred lexical label for a resource, in a given language. No two concepts in the same concept scheme may have the same preferred label in a given language.
A related resource that is included either physically or logically in the described resource.
A related resource in which the described resource is physically or logically included.

section.title: skosxl:Label
section.p: The class skosxl:Label is a special class of lexical entities. An instance of the class skosxl:Label is a resource and may be named with a URI.

An instance of the class skosxl:Label has a single literal form. This literal form is an RDF plain literal (which is a string of UNICODE characters and an optional language tag [RDF-CONCEPTS]). The property skosxl:literalForm is used to give the literal form of an skosxl:Label. If two instances of the class skosxl:Label have the same literal form, they are not necessarily the same resource.

entry.p: Date of creation of the resource.
Date of modification of the resource.

A related resource from which the described resource is derived in whole or in part. Recommended best practice is to identify the related resource by means of a string conforming to a formal identification system.
End of the validity period. If a resource has an end date then it must be marked as deprecated.
Beginning of the validity period.
Indicates the status of a resource in the process of asset management.
The characteristic of a word indicating that in a given discourse community, its referent is considered to be alive or to possess a quality of volition or consciousness.
A grammatical category that indicates grammatical variation in numerals. This feature is used in Maltese language.
A grammatical category that indicates grammatical relationships between words in sentences.
Grammatical category for the variation in form of nouns, pronouns, and any words agreeing with them, depending on how many persons or things are referred to.
In many languages, the grammatical distinction that indicates the number of objects referred to by the term or word.
States whether the resource is current or deprecated. By deprecating a resource, it means that it should not be used in new documents.
Deprecation is a feature commonly used in versioning software to indicate that a particular feature is preserved for backward-compatibility purposes, but may be phased out in the future.
An owl:versionInfo statement generally has as its object a string giving information about this version. This statement does not contribute to the logical meaning of the resource.
The literal form of an skosxl:Label. An instance of the class skosxl:Label has one and only one literal form.

row.entry: Specify the context where a specified notation is considered unique.

section.title: rdfs:Literal
section.p: The class rdfs:Literal is the class of literal values such as strings and integers. Property values such as textual strings are examples of RDF literals.

section.title: xsd:boolean
section.p: The boolean data type is used to specify a true or false value.

section.title: xsd:date
section.p: The date data type is used to specify a date. The date is specified in the following form "YYYY-MM-DD" where:
